revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Website | name = Fail Blog | logo = [[Image:Fail blog.png|120px]] | language = [[English language|English]] | type = Entertainment | slogan = Helping you feel better about yourself every day | location = United States | current status = Online | owner = | author = [http://failblog.org/author/leechio/ Leechio] | alexa = 984<ref>http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/failblog.org</ref> | launch date = 3 January 2008<ref name="firstfail">[http://failblog.org/2008/01/03/classic-baby/ Classic Baby] on Fail Blog</ref> | url = [http://failblog.org/ FailBlog.org] }} '''Fail Blog''' (typeset as '''FAIL Blog''') is a comedic [[blog]] website created in January 2008.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/09/magazine/09FOB-onlanguage-t.html | title=How Fail Went From Verb to Interjection | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=Aug. 7, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009 | first=Ben | last=Zimmer}}</ref>
==History== In January 2008, FAIL Blog was launched, with a picture of a warning sign featuring a drawing of a baby stuck in a stroller as the siteâs first upload.<ref name=firstfail/> The site grew steadily in popularity; in May 2008, FAIL Blog was sold to Pet Holdings Inc. (now [[Cheezburger Inc.]]), becoming part of the [[Cheezburger Network]].<ref name="slate">{{cite news | url=http://www.slate.com/id/2214241/ | title=I Can Has Internet Millions: The company behind lolcats and Failblog tries to turn memes into money | publisher=''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' | date=Mar. 20, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref> Huh notes that FAIL Blog "really started to take off when the financial industry decided to â ahem â fail."<ref name=nytimes/> As an example, at a Senate hearing in September 2008, a demonstrator held up a sign reading âFAILâ behind [[Henry Paulson]]., the former Treasury secretary, and [[Ben Bernanke]], chairman of the [[Federal Reserve]].<ref name=nytimes/> By January 2010, FAIL Blog was receiving 1.1 million unique visitors per month.<ref name=wired>Raftery, Brian. [http://www.wired.com/magazine/2010/01/mf_cheezking/ King of Cheez: The Internetâs Meme Maestro Turns Junk Into Gold]. ''Wired''. January 25, 2010.</ref> FAIL Blog's first book, ''Fail Nation: A Visual Romp Through the World of Epic Fails'', was released on October 6, 2009.<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/21/pre-order-your-copy-of-fail-nation/ Pre-order Your Copy of FAIL Nation], ''Failblog.org'', Jul. 21, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref><ref name=timestranscript>[http://timestranscript.canadaeast.com/opinion/article/1426256 Moncton is a safe place despite the crime that does happen]. ''Times Transcript''. July 25, 2011.</ref>
==Site structure== FAIL Blog chronicles disastrous mishaps and general stupidity in photos and video.<ref name=nytimes/> Users can upload a picture of someone or (something) failing at an activity, and have the option of captioning it with the words "[[Failure#Internet memes|fail]]", "epic fail", "X Fail", or "X; You're doin' it wrong" (X being the activity at which the subject has failed). There are also multiple sites under the FAIL Blog brand, including Failbook (which features FAILâs on [[Facebook]]), WIN!, Ugliest Tattoos, and There, I Fixed It and [[Meme (Internet)|Memebase]].<ref>[http://failbook.failblog.org/ Failbook]. Official Website.</ref><ref>[http://thereifixedit.failblog.org/ There I Fixed It]. ''Official Website''.</ref><ref>[http://wins.failblog.org/ WIN!].</ref><ref>[http://ugliesttattoos.failblog.org/ Ugliest Tattoos]. Official Website.</ref><ref>[http://memebase.failblog.org/ Memebase]. Official Website.</ref>
==Reception and influence== FAIL Blog won two [[Webby Awards]] in 2009, for People's Voice in Humor and Weird.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.channelapa.com/2009/06/fail-blog-wins-2009-webby-award.html | title=Fail Blog wins 2009 Webby Award | publisher=''ChannelAPA.com'' | date=Jun. 9, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref><ref name=people>Orlaff, Brian. [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20276622,00.html Sarah Silverman, Jimmy Fallon Win Big at the Webbys]. ''People''. May 5, 2009.</ref> The site has been profiled in most world publications: the [[The Times]] named FAIL blog their #3 comedy website, [[The Los Angeles Times]] called FAIL Blog, a "fan favorite," [[Time Magazine]] noted that FAIL Blog has "helped popularize fail as both a noun and an exclamation, not to mention an easier-to-spell synonym for schadenfreude," and the [[New York Times]] called it a ârunaway hit.â<ref name=nytimes/><ref name=timesonline>Whitwell, Tom. [http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/the_web/article3304328.ece Microtrends: Failure]. ''The Times''. February 9, 2008.</ref><ref name=time>Fitzpatrick, Laura. [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1916286,00.html#ixzz1U740AdfJ Building a Media Empire Around I Can Has Cheezburger]. ''TIME''. August 24, 2009.</ref><ref name=latimes>Mcedward, Laura. [http://articles.latimes.com/2008/sep/23/business/fi-benhuh23 Entrepreneurâs Kitty Site Now A Caboodle]. ''The Los Angeles Times''. September 23, 2008.</ref> The site is also commonly referenced in popular culture; [[The Huffington Post]] called [[Netflix]] a âwalking failblogâ in reference to their July 2011 pricing change and [[The Atlantic]] called a [[Chris Coghlan]] baseball blunder "a debacle worthy of FAIL Blog."<ref name=theatlantic>Simspon, Jake. [http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2010/07/beyond-chris-coghlan-top-5-sports-celebration-fails/60502/ Beyond Chris Coghlan: Top 5 Sports Celebration Fails]. ''The Atlantic''. July 28, 2010.</ref><ref name=huffpo>Gilbert, Jason. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/07/28/netflix-despite-the-price_n_912542.html Netflix, Despite The Price Hike And Nightmare PR, Is Still The Best In Field]. Huffington Post. July 29, 2011.</ref>
In July 2009, FAIL Blog posted a screenshot of the [[Guinness record]] webpage for "Most Individuals Killed in A Terrorist Attack" which was accompanied with a "Break this record" link. Guinness threatened legal action, and the story was picked up by [[TechCrunch]] and [[CNET]].<ref>[http://failblog.org/2009/07/13/omg-u-fail-so-hard/ OMG YOU FAIL SO HARD]. ''Failblog.org''. July 13, 2009, Retrieved Sept. 9, 2009</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cnet.com/8301-13952_1-10286349-81.html| title=The 404 381: Where we gotta stay positive| publisher=''[[CNET Networks|CNET News]]'' | date=July 14, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.techcrunch.com/2009/07/13/guinness-world-records-reaches-new-levels-of-fail/| title=Guinness World Records Reaches New Levels Of Fail| publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=July 13, 2009 | accessdate=Sept. 9, 2009}}</ref> FAIL Blogâs [[YouTube]] channel is the #15 most-subscribed channel of all-time, with more than 1.7 billion views.<ref>[http://www.youtube.com/user/failblog FAIL blog] on ''YouTube.com''.</ref>
FAIL Blog also has had a big impact on common vocabulary. It is now a household term to say "Fail" when people do things that are considered "Fail".
